title: Meet the R-HTA in LMICs Committee
text:
Meet the R-HTA in LMICs Committee
The R-HTA in LMICs team comprises individuals from around the world with diverse backgrounds, all passionate about improving healthcare decision-making through open-source tools and collaborative learning.

Co-Chairs








Buhle Ndweni


Lecturer in Health Economics


Buhle Ndweni is Co-chair and founding director of the ‚ÄòR-HTA in LMICs‚Äô Chapter. She‚Äôs currently a PhD Candidate at the University of Cape Town, South Africa, where she‚Äôs part of an NIHR Global health Research funded clinical trial investigating fungal infections in patients living with advanced HIV disease. She holds an MSc Health Economics and Decision Modelling (MSc HEDM) degree from the University of Sheffield, UK. She is skilled in building economic models and performing data analysis using Excel, VBA, R, STATA, Simul8 and WinBUGS (for Bayesian analysis using Markov chain Monte Carlo methods). Ndweni is passionate about global health research and finding innovative solutions to improve access to affordable, quality healthcare for all, especially disadvantaged communities in LMICs. She is on a quest to make a significant contribution in healthcare development and investment across the African continent and beyond. linkedin: https://www.linkedin.com/in/buhle-n-04a5661a/

Show more 











Joshua Soboil


Health Economist


Joshua is a Co-Chair and founding member of R-HTA in LMICs. Joshua enjoys problem solving and has developed a special love for evidence synthesis and advanced health economic decision-modelling techniques, using languages such as BUGS/JAGS and Stan coupled with R. His own work includes the ongoing development of a sensitivity analysis framework for HTA in Middle-Income Countries (MICs)

Show more 







Scientific Committee Members








Carina Behr


Health Economist


Carina is a health economist with a background in industrial engineering. Her expertise lie in complex simulation modelling. She holds a BSc and an MSc in Industrial engineering from the University of Pretoria and University of Twente, respectively. Carina completed her PhD in health economic modelling, also at the University of Twente in the Netherlands, where her research focused on a multi-disease screening program. Carina is currently working as a health economist at Lumanity, building and adapting global cost-effectiveness models for reimbursement submissions in various countries.

Show more 











Islem Meherzi


Data Science Engineer


Islem is a Senior Data Science Engineer with over 8 years of experience specializing in healthcare data solutions. She is also a researcher dedicated to advancing healthcare innovation through cutting-edge research projects that leverage health data. She has successfully led projects in Data Science, Robotic Process Automation (RPA) for data, Natural Language Processing (NLP), automated testing, and containerization. Her expertise spans a variety of core tools and techniques, including R programming, DevOps practices, and Quarto. Islem combines deep technical knowledge with a strong passion for problem-solving, collaboration, and knowledge sharing to deliver impactful solutions that improve healthcare outcomes.

Show more 











Satoshi Koiso, MDP, BVSc


Research Specialist


Satoshi is a research specialist with expertise in health policy and decision analyses, focusing on simulation modeling and cost-effectiveness evaluations. He holds a Bachelor of Veterinary Science from the University of Tokyo and a Master of Development Practice from UC Berkeley. His research spans disease modeling, public health strategies, and global health policy, driven by a commitment to advancing evidence-based decision-making in resource-limited settings. As a Science Committee member of R-HTA in LMICs, Satoshi leverages his proficiency in R to support health technology assessment and foster capacity-building among researchers and practitioners in low- and middle-income countries.

Show more 











Hannibal Musarurwa


Senior Lecturer


Hannibal Tafadzwa Musarurwa is a distinguished senior academic at the Medical School of Walter Sisulu University in Mthatha. With a robust background in biotechnology, molecular biology, science communication, and biostatistics, he has significantly advanced research in traditional medicine as well as cardiovascular and metabolic physiology. Currently, his academic endeavours focus on the pivotal roles of traditional health practitioners in rural communities and the effects of antiretroviral drugs on the microbiome. Adopting a transdisciplinary and interdisciplinary approach, he seamlessly connects scientific research with community health, championing holistic and inclusive healthcare delivery in culturally and epidemiologically diverse low- and middle-income settings. Moreover, he plays an active role in scientific committees that empower scientists and researchers from these regions to utilise R for health technology assessments, while also serving as a judge for PAICTA hackathons.

Show more 











Federico Rodriguez Cairoli


Medical Doctor


HTA researcher with a focus on pharmacoeconomics and epidemiology at IECS.

Show more

title: Get in Touch
text:
We‚Äôd love to hear from you! Whether you have questions, feedback, or ideas, feel free to reach out using the form below.


Your Name 
Your Email 
Message


Send Message

üìö Books & References


Recommended books for HTA using R



R for Health Technology Assessment: A comprehensive guide to the end-to-end use of R in health technology assessment (HTA), covering survival analysis, decision trees, multistate models, network meta-analysis, and discrete event simulation ‚Äî all explained through real-world examples with annotated R code. Ideal for HTA modellers, regulators, and health economists, enriched with case studies contributed by community members.

Authors: Gianluca Baio, Howard Thom, Petros Pechlivanoglou


Our Community Contributors: Buhle Ndweni, Joshua Soboil, Federico Cairoli






üî∞ Basic R


Introduction to R programming and scripting



Intro2R script: Input/output and object manipulation


Intro tutorial materials: Hands-on R learning materials from the June workshop





üîÅ Intermediate Modelling


Modeling tools based on DARTH group‚Äôs materials



Time-Dependent Models paper (2022): Introduction to time-dependent decision models


Simulation script: R script for simulating time-dependent models


State-residence time model: Simulating state-residence times


Functions for analysis: R functions used for HTA model simulations





üöÄ Advanced & Interactive Modelling


Advanced models and Shiny apps



Advanced HIV Markov model in R: Full workflow of a health economic Markov model


Explore interactive app: Interactive HIV model using Shiny





üìò Additional Resources


Recommended open learning materials



DARTH Decision Modeling Course: Free online course in health decision modeling


ISPOR Modeling Guidelines: Modeling practices and HTA methodology


Decision Modelling in Health Economic Evaluation (book): Key textbook for HTA decision modeling

title: About R-HTA in LMICs
text:
R-HTA is a consortium focused on promoting the use of R for health economics and health technology assessment (HTA). While its core members are from the Americas and the UK‚Äîrepresenting government institutions like NICE, academia, and industry‚ÄîR-HTA aims to serve a global community of analysts.



To empower LMIC (low- and middle-income countries) health systems with cutting-edge, reproducible, and accessible analytical tools for HTA using the R language.
Learn more about our workshops and learning resources designed to build skills for both beginners and experienced practitioners.




The R-HTA in LMICs chapter is the regional arm of the R-HTA consortium. Its mission is to: - Introduce R as a viable alternative to costly software - Support LMIC analysts and institutions in adopting R for HTA - Share tailored educational resources and workshops
We believe that open-source tools like R can help bridge the digital and economic divide in health analysis, fostering a community that thrives on collaboration and shared innovation.




HTA in LMICs is often constrained by: - Heavy reliance on proprietary software like Microsoft Excel and TreeAge - Limited budgets and access to advanced tools - Lack of hands-on, practical R training for HTA analysts
Meanwhile, health systems in LMICs are rapidly evolving, especially under the drive toward Universal Health Coverage (UHC). This creates a growing need for: - Complex modelling (e.g.¬†oncology, rare diseases) - Scalable and reproducible tools - Local capacity-building
Contact us to discuss how we can help bring these capabilities to your institution.





Workshops & Training Opportunities ‚Äî covering R, Health Technology Assessment (HTA), essential R packages, and practical tips for applying R in diverse contexts. Explore more on our Workshops page.
Advanced tutorials ‚Äî building cost-effectiveness models and interactive apps using Shiny.
Free resources and code ‚Äî all available on our GitHub.

We work side-by-side with partners, offering mentoring, technical assistance, and bespoke solutions for regional health needs.




Scalable
R handles complex HTA models more efficiently than spreadsheet-based tools. Read more
Reproducible
With Git, RMarkdown, and Shiny, models can be: - Shared with version control - Easily updated - Delivered as interactive tools
Open and Community-Driven
R‚Äôs vibrant health economics ecosystem includes: - BCEA - heemod - hesim - dampack




We welcome collaborators and learners alike‚Äîjoin us in building a stronger foundation for HTA in LMICs using R.
Visit our contact page to connect with our team.

title: About R-HTA
text:
R-HTA is a consortium focused on promoting the use of R for health economics and health technology assessment (HTA). The R for HTA in LMICs chapter is dedicated to introducing and showcasing the strengths of R programming to HTA analysts and healthcare institutions in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs). It hosts an annual workshop and quarterly tutorials, providing a platform where LMIC students and members of partner organisations can present their work, share experiences, and learn a wide range of R-based public health analysis techniques.



To empower LMIC (low- and middle-income countries) health systems with cutting-edge, reproducible, and accessible analytical tools for HTA using the R language.
Learn more about our workshops and learning resources designed to build skills for both beginners and experienced practitioners.




The R-HTA in LMICs chapter is the regional arm of the R-HTA consortium. Its mission is to:

Introduce R as a viable alternative to costly software
Support LMIC analysts and institutions in adopting R for HTA
Share tailored educational resources and workshops

We believe that open-source tools like R can help bridge the digital and economic divide in health analysis, fostering a community that thrives on collaboration and shared innovation.




HTA in LMICs is often constrained by: - Heavy reliance on proprietary software like Microsoft Excel and TreeAge - Limited budgets and access to advanced tools - Lack of hands-on, practical R training for HTA analysts
Meanwhile, health systems in LMICs are rapidly evolving, especially under the drive toward Universal Health Coverage (UHC). This creates a growing need for: - Complex modelling (e.g.¬†oncology, rare diseases) - Scalable and reproducible tools - Local capacity-building
Contact us to discuss how we can help bring these capabilities to your institution.





Workshops & Training Opportunities ‚Äî covering R, Health Technology Assessment (HTA), essential R packages, and practical tips for applying R in diverse contexts. Explore more on our Workshops page.
Advanced tutorials ‚Äî building cost-effectiveness models and interactive apps using Shiny.
Free resources and code ‚Äî all available on our GitHub.

We work side-by-side with partners, offering mentoring, technical assistance, and bespoke solutions for regional health needs.




Scalable
R handles complex HTA models more efficiently than spreadsheet-based tools. Read more
Reproducible
With Git, RMarkdown, and Shiny, models can be: - Shared with version control - Easily updated - Delivered as interactive tools
Open and Community-Driven
R‚Äôs vibrant health economics ecosystem includes: - BCEA - heemod - hesim - dampack




We welcome collaborators and learners alike‚Äîjoin us in building a stronger foundation for HTA in LMICs using R.
Visit our contact page to connect with our team.

title: R for HTA in LMICs
text:
Who We Are
R-HTA in LMICs is the regional chapter of the global R-HTA consortium.
We promote the use of R for HTA in LMICs through open-access tutorials, workshops, and resources.
Learn More

title: R for HTA in LMICs
text:
What We Do



Tutorials

Hands-on R training for health economists.

Browse our Workshops ¬ª 




Resources

Curated tools and links for R and HTA.

 Explore R + HTA Tools ¬ª




Events

Workshops led by international experts.

View All Past Events ¬ª

title: R for HTA in LMICs
text:
Get Involved

Visit our GitHub repository
Contact us ‚Äî Have a question or collaboration idea? We‚Äôd love to hear from you!
Join our mailing list via the R-HTA main site

title: Workshops
text:
The R-HTA in LMICs chapter hosts annual workshops showcasing R applications in health economics from students, academics, and professionals in LMICs.


üìÖ 2025




Day 1 ‚Äì Part 1: Overview of R Programming


Islem Meherzi


Introduction to R fundamentals and real-world applications in HTA.


 GitHub  Slides  YouTube




Day 1 ‚Äì Part 2: Data Manipulation and Web Scraping in R


Islem Meherzi


Using dplyr and rvest to prepare and scrape data for HTA workflows.


 GitHub  Slides  YouTube




Day 2 ‚Äì Cost-Effectiveness in R-HTA Modelling




Practical workshop on implementing cost-effectiveness models in R for HTA.


 GitHub  YouTube







üìÖ 2024




Introduction to R for HTA 2024




Getting to grips with R for basic survival analysis and health economic analysis.


 GitHub  YouTube







üìÖ 2022




Introduction




Introduction to the chapter and team motivation.


 YouTube

Joshua Soboil


Tutorial on using GitHub with R and RStudio.

Dr Nathan Green


Introduction to the BCEA package for decision modelling.


 YouTube  Article




Shiny for HTA


Rose Hart & Robert Smith


Shiny for HTA


Rose Hart & Robert Smith


Wrapping health economic models in Shiny for interactivity.

FGM Cost Model


David Tordup


WHO-commissioned model on FGM in 27 countries.


 YouTube  Article

Yi-Shu Lin


A lightweight model for teaching screening cost-effectiveness.

Budget Impact Analysis


Dr Federico Cairoli


A Shiny calculator for budget impact.


 YouTube  App




Modelling COVID in R


Dr Ivan Zimmerman


Using R instead of Excel for SIR models.


 YouTube

Dr Alejandro Lopez Osornio


Cost-effectiveness analysis of COVID-19 vaccines.


 GitHub  YouTube  App

Dr Fernando Escudero


Framework for improving transparency in R decision modelling.

üïì Past Events




Introduction to R for HTA Modelling ‚Äì 25 September 2023


Date: September 25, 2023


This half-day interactive tutorial trained LMIC health analysts on using R for HTA modelling. No prior R experience was required.

View Resources




Advanced R-HTA Modelling ‚Äì 20 January 2023


Date: January 20, 2023


Participants learned how to convert Excel-based models to R and build interactive tools with Shiny.

View Resources




Intermediary R-HTA Tutorial ‚Äì 20 September 2022


Date: September 20, 2022


Hands-on workshop on sick-sicker models using R. Built on knowledge from Q2 tutorial.

View Resources




Introductory R-HTA Tutorial ‚Äì 21 June 2022


Date: June 21, 2022


Participants gained practical skills using DARTH in a simple sick-sicker model.

View Resources
